section1.p: is a tool that works as a utility in (aka ). can use a to disambiguate a text or a portion of a text that has been analyzed in a project. You tell the file to use. Then you can choose a text or a portion of that text and ask to try and disambiguate it.
works with version or higher of and is only available on 64-bit Windows computers.
While you can use any file, expects that you will have used the program to create the file. See https://software.sil.org/paws/ for more on .

section2.p: To install , obtain the installer from https://​github.com/​sillsdev/pcpatrflex/​tree/​master/​Installer/​Output/​UsePcPatrWithFLExDllSetup.exe. The installer will check to see if you have installed version 9. If not, it will abort.
We recommend that you close before running the installer.
While running , use Tools menu item / Utilities.... Find the “Use PC-PATR with FLEx” item, check it, and then click on the “Run Checked Utilities Now” button.
The first time you invoke on a database, it will automatically add to your database the following:

ol.li: a custom field to each sense (called “PCPATR”) and
a custom list (called “PCPATR Feature Descriptors”) containing the template names that the generated by the program expects.

section2.p: The names shown above are always in the English analysis writing system and English is the only writing system containing these names.
You can find the custom list by clicking on the “Lists” button in .
looks like what is shown in .
The texts in the database are shown in the left pane and the segments of the first text are shown in the right pane.
There are buttons you can click. Each is discussed in section below.

section1.p: You control by using the various buttons. This section briefly describes them. See sections – for more on what happens for the segment and text buttons, respectively.

section2.p: To choose which file to use, click on the Browse button. By convention, files have an extension of “.grm” so this is what the file browser uses.

allows you to have “rootglosses” in rules. This section allows you to set one of four options with respect to how rootglosses are handled. See section 3.2.14.22 “set rootgloss” in the PC-PATR Reference Manual.
Use the Help menu item / PC-PATR Reference Manual to see this document. The four options are:

ol.li: off: rootglosses are not used; this is the default;
leftmost root: the first / leftmost root is used;
rightmost root: the last / rightmost root is used;
all: every root is used.

section2.p: The “Help...” button is used to get this user documentation file, show the PC-PATR Reference Manual, or to show the “About” dialog box.
Above the pane containing the texts is a button labeled “Disambiguate & show this text.” You use this button to try and use the to disambiguate this entire text. See section for more.

Above the pane containing the segments of the selected text is a button labeled “Parse & show this segment.” You use this button to try and use the to parse this particular segment. See section for more.

section1.p: When you use the “Parse & show this segment” button for a segment or double click on that segment, will pass the parsing information that you entered in to , along with the , and process that segment. The result will be shown in a slightly newer version of the tool (https://​software.​sil.​org/​carla/​pc-patr-browser/). See appendix for more information on this tool.

You use this tool to see all the parses the program produced for this segment using the file. When there are two or more parses, you can show the correct one and then use Parse / Use This Parse menu item (or click on the tool bar button) to have this analysis be recorded in the database for this segment. That is, this segment will be disambiguated, using the information from this parse.

If you are using the TreeTran program, you can save the results of the disambiguated parses in a file called Invoker.xml in the %TEMP% directory. You do this by using File / Save for TreeTran to make sure there is a check mark before it. Alternatively, you can click on the item in the tool bar.
When you are done looking at the results, close the tool and you will return to .

When you use the “Disambiguate & show this text” button, will pass the parsing information for all segments in the text to , along with the , and process all those segments. Since all the segments are processed, this will probably take a while. So please be patient. The result will be shown in the slightly newer version of the tool. See appendix for more information on this tool.
Unlike with parsing a segment (see section ), the result will have as many “sentences” as there are segments in the text.

By default, will disambiguate a segment in the database whenever the result of the parsing uniquely identifies the analysis of each word in the segment. For those cases where there are still ambiguities, you can use the tool to select a given parse to use. Like with parsing a segment, you show the correct parse and then use Parse / Use This Parse menu item (or click on the tool bar button) to have this analysis be recorded in the database for this segment. That is, this segment will be disambiguated, using the information from this parse.
When you are done looking at the results, close the tool and you will return to .
Whenever you exit and restart , it will do the following:

ol.li: remember which file you last chose;
remember which text in that project you last selected; and
remember which segment in that text you last selected.

section1.p: In certain situations, will issue an error message.
Example lists the errors reports along with a brief description of what the error might mean.

td.object: The PC-PATR grammar file had an error in it and failed to load. We will show the error log after you click on OK. Please fix all errors in the grammar file and then try again.

tr.td:
The file being used has at least one error it it so the program could not load and use it. The list of errors (and any warning messages, too) will be shown as soon as you click on the OK button. Note that in the error message file, the grammar file's location may look odd, but it is the same as what is showing before the “Browse” button.
This happens for long file names or folder names. is a “DOS” program and uses this cryptic format. Also, the error messages and warnings may be a bit cryptic. See the PC-PATR Reference Manual for (some possible) help on this. (The manual is available via the "Help” button; see section .)

td.object: The following glosses contain a space. Please fix them and try again.

tr.td: At least one gloss used in one of the segments has a space in it. This will produce incorrect values in some of the files used. You will continue to get this message until you find and fix the gloss. You should be able to search for the gloss in Lexicon Edit in .

section1.p: If you get an error message not in the list above, please report it. See section .
The following items are known to be less than desirable with this version of :

ol.li: only works with version or higher of .
assumes that the comment character in the file is a vertical bar |. If you use something else, the parser will fail every segment.

When a word in does not have the “Word Cat" field filled out for a word in the interlinear, will try and guess what the category of the word should be. It does this as follows:
If there is only one morpheme, use its category.
If there are two or more morphemes and only one stem/root, find the stem and use its category. (This could be incorrect if one of the affixes is derivational and changes the category.)
If there are two or more stems, use the category of the left-most one. (This could be incorrect if some other stem is the correct category to use or if the stem compounding results in a different category or if one of the affixes is derivational and changes the category.)Therefore, it is always a good idea to overtly fill out the “Word Cat” field in .
When a morpheme in a word analysis has just the form but no sense or grammatical info, then the gloss showing in the output will be the gloss of the first sense of the entry for the morpheme.

When a morpheme in a word analysis has the form and grammatical info but no sense overtly indicated and there are two or more senses using the grammatical info in the entry, then the gloss showing in the output will be the gloss of the first sense which uses the grammatical info.
The user interface is in English only.

section1.p: If you have any questions with or find bugs in it, please send an email to blackhandrew@gmail.com.

appendix.p: This appendix briefly covers the various parts of the tool.

section1.p: Example is a screen shot of what it looks like for one segment using one .
There are four panes:

ol.li: the segment in an interlinear form (at the top);
the syntactic tree, if any (left, middle);
the feature structure of the selected node in the tree (right, middle); and
the file used (bottom)

section1.p: When a node in the tree is selected, the bottom pane will show the rule in the file that produced that node. In addition, the features for that selected node will appear in the right, middle pane. For example, when clicking on the IP node, it looked like example .

When there is more than one segment, you can use the Sentence menu item options or the first set of arrow buttons on the tool bar to navigate from one sentence to another. See appendix for keyboard shortcuts. (Please note that with , “sentence” is the same as “segment.”)

When there is more than one parse for a given segment, you can use the Parse menu item options or the second set of arrow buttons on the tool bar to navigate from one parse to another. See appendix for keyboard shortcuts.
When you manually select to use a parse, then the entire tree description will be highlighted in yellow. In addition, the sentence number in the interlinear pane will be highlighted in yellow.

If the vernacular language of your project is a right-to-left script, will try to tell the this. You may need to use the Language menu item, though, and uncheck and then check the “Use right-to-left orientation in parse tree and interlinear” option.

To make processing texts faster, there are several keyboard shortcuts available. These only work when the “focus" is in the interlinear, tree, or feature panes. When begins, the default is to have the “focus” on the feature pane. If you have clicked in the grammar file pane or if you are using the keyboard to select a menu item, then these shortcuts will not work. You will need to click in the interlinear, tree, or feature pane first.
The shortcuts are as in example :

tr.td: Use this parse & go to next sentence

endnote.p: Some keyboards may not work with this sequence. Therefore we also offer the Ctrl+L option.

appendix.secTitle: Another way to edit a file
appendix.p: One challenge with editing a file is that it is a plain text file. If one wants to try and debug a grammar, one has to comment off a large amount of lines. It can get to be tricky.
Some tentative work has been done on a tool that will take a file and convert it to a form that can be used in a tool like the . Some advantages of this are that one can:

ol.li: Quickly enable/disable given rules
Quickly enable/disable given templates

appendix.p: A major disadvantage is that once converted to this form, large files are quite slow to load into the .s
If you are interested in trying this, please contact blackhandrew@gmail.com.

types.comment: The following types are provided as pre-set examples. You may well want to create your own types that refer to one or more of these. You do that by typing in the names of the types in the types attribute of your type.
